data: Concave marble plaque set in plaster in modern times.
Letters with serifs: Α with broken bar, quadrate Ε, square lunate Σ, rhomboid Θ, cursive Ω (Ω at l. 5 as a Μ upside down). Letters at ll. 1-2 are slightly larger than letters in the following lines.
Original discovery not recorded, probably from Catania (possibly Siracusa).
Observed by Blackburne (cod. Oxford, coll. Onions, f. 6) and Kaibel in Museo Biscari, later by Korhonen in magazzino del cortile, collezione Biscari (formerly sala VI, 70).
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana
Castello Ursino, Piazza Federico II di Svevia, 95121 Catania (CT)

Torremuzza, Ferrara: Εὐαίριος; Franz: Εὐκαίριος; Kaibel, Ferrua, Agnello, Wessel: Εὐάγριος
Franz: μου; Torremuzza, Kaibel, Wessel: ἐμοῦ; Ferrua: μοι; Ferrara, Agnello, Korhonen, lapis: ἐμοί
Κωπάντις lapis, Torremuzza, Ferrara; Franz: Κωτιαν; Kaibel, Ferrua, Agnello, Wessel; Korhonen: Κωαντίς
My lord Euagrios freely gave this tomb to me, Theodoulos, and here lie Kostantis and Kekilia.
Il mio signore Euagrios ha donato questa tomba a me, Theodoulos, e qui giacciono Kostantis e Kaikilia.

This inscription attests to the donation of a tomb (denoted by the word  as recurring in Christian inscriptions) by Euagrios to Theodoulos, in which Kostantis and Kaikilia (probably his daughters, according to Führer-Schultze 1907: 13) are buried: donations of tombs are not frequent in Christian epigraphy, where there are more mentions of the purchase of the tomb (see ICR 980, Grossi Gondi 1920: 248). The term  does not have the meaning of “master” here and does not allude to a slavery condition of the beneficiary (as Führer-Schultze 1907: 13), but has a connotation of respect as in IG 14.525 = . The names ,  (= ),  (= ) and  are attested in Christian inscriptions, but the last is not attested elsewhere in Sicily:  is attested also in a Christian inscription from Catania IG 14.538 = ,  in an inscription from Tauromenion (3rd-4th cent. CE),  is frequent in Sicily (LGPN 3A:227). As Korhonen (2004: 257) remarks, the formula and onomastics of the inscription could be from Syracuse, but its presence in the collezione Biscari as early as 1749, when Blackburne observed it, and the fact that there are no other Syracusan Christian inscriptions in the collection argues in favour of a provenance from Catania.

l.1 ς

Apparatus criticus

  • Text based on photographs;
  • line.1: ΟΚΟΡΙΟΕΜΟΥ lapis
  • lines.1-2: Torremuzza, Ferrara: Εὐαίριος; Franz: Εὐκαίριος; Kaibel, Ferrua, Agnello, Wessel: Εὐάγριος
  • line.3: Franz: μου; Torremuzza, Kaibel, Wessel: ἐμοῦ; Ferrua: μοι; Ferrara, Agnello, Korhonen, lapis: ἐμοί
  • line.5: Κωπάντις lapis, Torremuzza, Ferrara; Franz: Κωτιαν; Kaibel, Ferrua, Agnello, Wessel; Korhonen: Κωαντίς

English translation

My lord Euagrios freely gave this tomb to me, Theodoulos, and here lie Kostantis and Kekilia.

Italian translation

Il mio signore Euagrios ha donato questa tomba a me, Theodoulos, e qui giacciono Kostantis e Kaikilia.

commentary

This inscription attests to the donation of a tomb (denoted by the word τόπος as recurring in Christian inscriptions) by Euagrios to Theodoulos, in which Kostantis and Kaikilia (probably his daughters, according to Führer-Schultze 1907: 13) are buried: donations of tombs are not frequent in Christian epigraphy, where there are more mentions of the purchase of the tomb (see ICR 980, Grossi Gondi 1920: 248). The term κύριος does not have the meaning of “master” here and does not allude to a slavery condition of the beneficiary (as Führer-Schultze 1907: 13), but has a connotation of respect as in IG 14.525 = ISic000964. The names Θεόδουλος, Κωστάντις (= Κωστάντιος), Κεκιλία (= Καικιλία) and Εὐάγριος are attested in Christian inscriptions, but the last is not attested elsewhere in Sicily: Θεόδουλος is attested also in a Christian inscription from Catania IG 14.538 = ISic001357, Κωστάντις in an inscription from Tauromenion (3rd-4th cent. CE), Καικιλία is frequent in Sicily (LGPN 3A:227). As Korhonen (2004: 257) remarks, the formula and onomastics of the inscription could be from Syracuse, but its presence in the collezione Biscari as early as 1749, when Blackburne observed it, and the fact that there are no other Syracusan Christian inscriptions in the collection argues in favour of a provenance from Catania.

CE), Καικιλία is frequent in Sicily (LGPN 3A:227).
